A tiny project focused on one thing: turn chaos into a short, daily mission list.
Why it exists #Most planning tools reward collecting tasks, not finishing them. Compass rewards finishing.
What it does # A daily mission list with a hard limit of 3 A one line outcome for each mission A graceful archive so you can see momentum How it works # Capture anything in a quick inbox. Promote only what matters to today. Ship three things, then stop. Screens # Compass in action Notes # Swap the example images with local assets later. Congo will optimize local images through Hugo Pipes.
summary: A small tool that turns messy tasks into clear, daily missions.

content:
Designing for attention starts with defending your own. This is a short field guide to protect focus without turning into a monk.
The Rule of One Window #Keep one intentional window open: the one where the work happens. Every extra tab is a tiny promise you will break later.
A Tiny Checklist # What must exist when I stop today? What is the smallest version that proves the idea? What can I delete without guilt? A Quote That Helps # If you donâ€™t guard your time, the internet will schedule it for you.
A Small Table # Signal Noise Replace With endless tabs false options a short list alerts fragmented time a single inbox vague goals drift a clear deliverable A Compact Timeline # Morning: produce the core artifact Midday: tighten and ship the smallest slice Evening: record what to fix next A Pull Quote # Make the work visible, make the scope small, make the finish real. A Callout # No tool will rescue a vague goal. Tools amplify clarity or confusion. An Image #Add a header image by placing an asset next to this file or in assets/ and referencing it in front matter.
A Little Math #When you care about sharpness, you pick fewer things and do them better.
37503\text{focus} = \frac{\text{intention}}{\text{distraction} + 1}37503
The Close #The hardest part of creating is making a clear line. I stop here so tomorrow has a place to begin.
summary: A field guide to protecting deep work in a world of pings.
